title: Replace CCV CLI flags with environment variables
description: Remove --verbose, --quiet, --format flags from CCV. Use environment variables instead (CCV_VERBOSE, CCV_QUIET, CCV_FORMAT). Keep only --help and --version. This eliminates the need for the -- separator when passing flags to claude.

title: Increase test coverage to 65%+ target
description:
Current test coverage is 56.1%, target is 65%+.

Areas with lower coverage that could be improved:
- runner.go: Wait(), Stop(), WriteInput() functions (0% coverage)
- runner.go: NewClaudeRunner() error paths
- output.go: ProcessMessages() channel handling
- types.go: AddOrUpdateToolCall() (60% coverage)
- types.go: CreateChildAgent() (85.7% coverage)
- types.go: ParseMessage() (77.8% coverage)

Note: Some functions like NewClaudeRunner require mocking the claude CLI which adds complexity.

title: Refactor processToolResult function (130 lines)
description:
Extract tool-specific handlers from processToolResult (output.go:273-403) using a dispatch map pattern. This will make each handler testable in isolation and reduce cyclomatic complexity.

Current state:
- Function is 130 lines with multiple if/else branches for different tool types
- Each tool type (Bash, Glob, Grep, etc.) has its own handling logic inline

Proposed solution:
```go
var toolResultHandlers = map[string]toolResultHandler{
    "Bash": handleBashResult,
    "Glob": handleGlobResult,
    "Grep": handleGrepResult,
    // etc.
}
```

Risk: Medium - functional refactoring
Priority: Low - optional improvement

title: CCV: Claude Code Viewer CLI Tool
description: Lightweight Go CLI that wraps claude with --output-format stream-json and renders structured text output showing assistant responses, tool calls, thinking blocks, and results. Headless CLI tool for use in scripts and automation.

title: Project setup and core type definitions
description: Initialize Go module with dependencies (bubbletea, lipgloss, bubbles). Create main.go with argument parsing. Define all SDK message type structs (SystemInit, Assistant, StreamEvent, Result, CompactBoundary). Define ContentBlock types (text, tool_use, thinking). Define ToolCall and AgentState structs.

title: Search tool renderers (Glob/Grep)
description: Implement text formatters for Glob/Grep search tools. Glob should show: '→ Glob: <pattern>' followed by file paths found. Grep should show: '→ Grep: <pattern>' followed by matches with file:line format. Keep output scannable.

title: Agent hierarchy renderer
description: Implement text formatter for showing agent hierarchy and context. Display current agent type and status inline (e.g., '[main: running]' or '[task: exploring]'). Show nesting with indentation when sub-agents are spawned via Task tool. Keep display compact and informative.

title: Final result summary renderer
description: Implement final result summary formatter. Shows session completion with: total tokens used, cost, duration, number of turns. Format as a summary block at the end. Include breakdown of input/output/cache tokens.

title: Integration testing and build setup
description: Build commands in Makefile. Test with simple prompts. Test with subagent prompts. Verify permission prompt forwarding works. Cross-compile for macOS, Linux, Windows.

title: README with curl one-liner installation
description:
Create a comprehensive README.md that includes:

## Requirements
- One-liner curl installation: `curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/REPO/main/install.sh | bash`
- Installation script (install.sh) that:
  - Detects OS (macOS, Linux)
  - Detects architecture (amd64, arm64)
  - Downloads the appropriate binary from GitHub releases
  - Installs to /usr/local/bin (or ~/.local/bin)
  - Verifies checksums

## README Content
- Project description and features
- Installation section with multiple methods:
  - One-liner curl install (recommended)
  - Go install: `go install github.com/REPO/cmd/ccv@latest`
  - Manual binary download
  - Build from source
- Usage examples
- Configuration options
- Requirements (claude CLI must be installed)
- Screenshots/demos (optional GIF)
- Contributing section
- License

title: Remove Bubble Tea TUI dependencies and code
description: Remove all Bubble Tea (bubbletea, lipgloss) dependencies from go.mod. Delete tui.go file. Refactor main.go to remove tea.NewProgram() and all TUI initialization code. The goal is to make ccv a headless CLI that outputs structured text to stdout instead of an interactive TUI.

title: Implement headless structured text output processor
description: Create a new text output processor that consumes messages from runner.messages channel and outputs formatted text to stdout. Should display: assistant text responses, thinking blocks (with [THINKING] prefix), tool calls (with tool name and status), tool results (indented), and token usage summary. Output should be clean, readable, and suitable for logging/piping.

title: Add output formatting flags
description: Add CLI flags to control output verbosity: --verbose (show all details including tool inputs), --quiet (only show assistant text), --format (text|json). Default should be structured text with moderate detail. JSON format should output the parsed SDK messages as clean JSON.

title: Add terminal colors for enhanced output rendering
description: Add ANSI colors to all terminal output actions for better visual distinction. This includes coloring for tool calls, thinking blocks, assistant text, agent context, and status indicators.

title: Skip mandatory flags if user already provides them
description: When spawning the claude CLI, avoid adding mandatory flags (--output-format stream-json, --include-partial-messages) if the user has already passed them in their arguments. This prevents duplicate or conflicting flags.

title: Claude subprocess runner and JSON stream parser
description: Create subprocess runner that spawns claude with injected flags (--output-format stream-json --include-partial-messages). Handle stdout/stderr/stdin piping. Forward stdin for permission prompts. Implement NDJSON line-by-line parser. Type detection and unmarshaling for each message type.

title: Bubble Tea model and core UI structure
description: Create main Bubble Tea model with state. Implement Init(), Update(), View() methods. Define Lip Gloss styles (colors, borders, spacing). Handle terminal resize events. Connect parser output to UI messages via channels.

title: Application state management
description: Implement AppState with agent tracking. Track tool calls by ID in PendingTools map. Build agent hierarchy from parent_tool_use_id field. Track token counts across all agents. Manage streaming state (partial text, partial tool input).

title: Token-counting spinner component
description: Token-counting spinner with animation using bubbles spinner. Show current agent context. Update token count from usage data in assistant messages. Handle start/stop states.

title: Generic tool call renderer
description: Implement text formatter for generic tool calls. Should output tool name, input parameters (formatted as readable text or JSON), and status (pending/running/completed/failed). Format: '→ Tool: <name> [<status>]' followed by indented parameters.

title: Bash tool output renderer
description: Implement text formatter for Bash tool calls and results. Should show the command being executed and the output. Format: '→ Bash: <command>' followed by indented stdout/stderr output. Preserve ANSI colors if present.

title: File operation renderers (Read/Write)
description: Implement text formatters for Read/Write file operations. Read should show: '→ Read: <file_path>' with line count. Write should show: '→ Write: <file_path>' with size or line count. Keep output concise.

title: Edit/MultiEdit diff renderer
description: Implement text formatter for Edit/MultiEdit operations showing diffs. Format: '→ Edit: <file_path>' followed by a unified diff-style output showing old vs new content. Use +/- prefixes for added/removed lines. Keep diffs readable and concise.

title: Analyze Claude Code codebase for complete SDK message and action coverage
description:
## Overview
Audit the Claude Code CLI codebase to identify ALL possible message types, tool calls, events, and actions that can be emitted via `--output-format stream-json`. Ensure CCV handles every case.

## Investigation Tasks

### 1. Message Types
- [ ] Identify all SDK message types (SystemInit, AssistantMessage, StreamEvent, Result, etc.)
- [ ] Check for any new/undocumented message types
- [ ] Verify all fields are captured in our type definitions

### 2. Content Block Types
- [ ] `text` - Regular assistant text
- [ ] `tool_use` - Tool invocations
- [ ] `tool_result` - Tool outputs
- [ ] `thinking` - Extended thinking blocks
- [ ] `redacted_thinking` - Redacted thinking
- [ ] Any other content block types?

### 3. Tool Types
Identify ALL built-in tools and their schemas:
- [ ] Read, Write, Edit, MultiEdit
- [ ] Bash, BashBackground
- [ ] Glob, Grep, LS
- [ ] Task (subagents)
- [ ] WebFetch, WebSearch
- [ ] TodoRead, TodoWrite
- [ ] NotebookRead, NotebookEdit
- [ ] AskFollowupQuestion
- [ ] MCP tools (dynamic)
- [ ] Any other tools?

### 4. Event Types
- [ ] All StreamEvent delta types
- [ ] Permission request events
- [ ] Agent spawn/complete events
- [ ] Error events
- [ ] Progress indicators

### 5. Special Cases
- [ ] Permission prompts and responses
- [ ] Interactive stdin handling
- [ ] Subagent hierarchy and nesting
- [ ] Background task management
- [ ] Rate limiting / retry signals
- [ ] Session management events

## Sources to Investigate
- Claude Code GitHub repo (if public)
- `claude --help` output for all flags
- Stream JSON output samples from various operations
- SDK documentation
- Any TypeScript/schema definitions

## Deliverables
1. Comprehensive list of all message/event types
2. Gap analysis: what CCV handles vs what exists
3. Updated types.go with any missing types
4. Test cases for edge cases

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All message types documented
- [ ] All tool types documented  
- [ ] All event types documented
- [ ] Gap analysis complete
- [ ] types.go updated if needed
- [ ] No unknown message types in production use

title: Enhanced terminal output formatting with colors, spacing, and improved visual hierarchy
description:
## Overview
Add rich terminal formatting to CCV output to make it visually appealing and easier to read, similar to how Claude Code displays its output.

## Visual Requirements

### Colors
- **Green**: File names, paths, success messages
- **Yellow/Gold**: Command names, flags, variable names
- **Cyan**: Environment variables, inline code references
- **White/Default**: Regular text content
- **Dim/Gray**: Line numbers, secondary info
- **Magenta**: Function names, method references
- **Red**: Errors, warnings

### Bullet Points and Icons
- Use filled bullet (●) for main output sections
- Use (L) or similar for line indicators in file changes
- Use (+) for additions, (-) for removals in diffs

### Spacing and Layout
- Proper indentation for nested content (2-4 spaces)
- Blank lines between major sections
- Code blocks should be clearly delineated
- Line numbers aligned and dimmed

### Code Block Formatting
- Show file name as header (e.g., `Update(ralph-zai.sh)`)
- Display line numbers on the left
- Syntax highlighting for common patterns:
  - Strings in quotes
  - Environment variables
  - Commands/binaries
  - Flags and options
- Show added lines with + prefix and green color
- Show context lines without prefix

### Structural Elements
- Tool calls: Arrow icon with colored tool name and status
- Thinking blocks: Distinct styling with prefix
- Agent context: Badges showing agent type and status
- Section separators when needed

## Technical Implementation

### Dependencies
Consider using:
- `github.com/fatih/color` - Simple color output
- `github.com/charmbracelet/lipgloss` - More advanced styling
- Or built-in ANSI escape codes for zero dependencies

### New Files/Components
- `colors.go` - Color definitions and theme
- `format.go` - Formatting utilities
- Update `output.go` - Apply formatting to output

### Configuration
- Respect `NO_COLOR` environment variable
- Auto-detect terminal color support
- Add `--no-color` flag option

### Test Considerations
- Test with different terminal emulators
- Test piping output (should strip colors)
- Test with NO_COLOR=1

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Assistant text displays with proper formatting
- [ ] Tool calls show with icons and colors
- [ ] Code blocks display with line numbers and syntax hints
- [ ] File paths highlighted in green
- [ ] Commands/variables highlighted appropriately
- [ ] Proper spacing between sections
- [ ] Colors disabled when piping or NO_COLOR set
- [ ] Works on macOS and Linux terminals

title: Render skill actions properly in output
description: Add proper rendering support for Skill tool invocations in the text output. When a Skill is invoked (e.g., /commit, /review-pr), display it with appropriate formatting showing the skill name and status, similar to how other tool calls are rendered.
